tool.name: CrossSections
tool.displayname: 2. Create Cross Sections and Routed Centerline

param.name: Input Centerline
param.dialogReference:
Input the Centerline Feature Class created in Step 1. This feature class should contain a single polyline feature that the user drew using Editor. The Centerline polyline must have a name saved in the ROUTEID column (can be text or numeric). The centreline captures the Valley centreline and not the river centreline.

This step utilizes "routes" to give a linear measure to the centerline (1m steps).

param.name: Route ID
param.dialogReference: The route ID will be auto-populated from the Centreline Feature Class.

param.name: Station Direction
param.displayname: Select Direction to Start Stationing From
param.dialogReference:
Choose the direction that the centerline stations and cross sections will accumulate from.

Select the direction you would like to build your Centerline Stations from (i.e. moving upstream, or moving downstream) based on the drawn centerline and direction of flow.

Do you like your longitudinal profiles to rise or fall when moving from left to right?

param.name: Valley Bottom Width
param.dialogReference:
Now input your Centerline Buffer Distance (m). This distance should ensure that each cross section extends to the valley toe slope.

There is not computational cost to extending your cross sections well beyond the toe slope. However, it dramatically increase the range of your relative elevations and make your initial stretched colour ramp less informative.

tool.summary: Create cross sections along the valley centerline at the defined cross section width. Spacing is assumed to be 1m apart as that is the expected resolution of the lidar dataset.
